newsitem.title: USA: Actress Pamela Anderson Lee says she no pushover.
newsitem.headline: Actress Pamela Anderson Lee says she no pushover.

text.p: Former "Baywatch" TV star Pamela Anderson Lee on Wednesday hailed her victory in a breach-of-contract lawsuit as showing the movie industry she was no "pushover."

"I think it sends a strong message to other actors," she told reporters. "I've got a lot of really good feedback from other actors who are really happy with the verdict and feel a lot more protected."

Lee's news conference came one day after a judge ruled in her favour in a lawsuit brought by a movie company alleging she broke a contract and backed out of a film project. The company sought $5 million.
"I think people now realise I'm not a pushover," said the actress who appeared to be basking in victory. Her laywers too, seemed elated with Tuesday's ruling.
"She made a decision to fight for the truth," said attorney Henry Holmes. "The case has changed the movie industry -- I hope for the good."
His reference was to the common Hollywood practice of making multi-million-dollar movie deals on a verbal agreement or a handshake.
Judge David Horowitz ruled The Private Movie Co. failed to prove "by a preponderance of evidence" that Lee entered into a contract to make the cable TV movie "Hello, She Lied."
In his written ruling, Horowitz said there was no binding agreement, despite the producer's claim that she had made an oral agreement to make the film.
During the non-jury trial, lawyers for the plaintiffs also acknowledged a written agreement with Lee was never executed.
The company claimed she broke a contract because she was offered a better deal to make a feature film, "Barb Wire."
Lee, married to rock drummer Tommy Lee of Motley Crue, said during testimony that she pulled out of the project because she objected to sex scenes in the proposed film.
"I don't feel comfortable with love-making scenes -- but nudity was never an issue," she said at the news conference.
"I felt I was being manipulated, I felt I was being taken advantage of and I did not want to settle this case (out of court)."
Lee's lawyer dismissed the film-makers' pledge to appeal the ruling, but plaintiffs' attorney Adam Miller told Reuters to "tell him to get his pen ready. We're appealing."
